entry.title: Anne Mills Archbold (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that two lion cubs that Anne Mills Archbold (pictured) brought to America as pets on the Lusitania became exhibits at the Bronx Zoo?

entry.title: Zinkiv (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Zinkiv, Ukraine, was a center of Hasidic Judaism until almost the entirety of the city's 2,300-strong Jewish population was murdered during the Holocaust?

entry.title: Ana Amado (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that due to her leftist beliefs, journalist Ana Amado was told not to come to work by her public television employer while her husband was on the death list of the Argentine Anticommunist Alliance?

entry.title: Minato's Laundromat (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Japanese manga series Minato's Laundromat originated as a story titled Wash My Heart! that was posted on Pixiv?

entry.title: Marek Obrtel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that former Czech Army doctor Marek Obrtel returned his military decorations from NATO operations in 2014, citing his pro-Russian and anti-American views?

entry.title: Acts of Peter and the Twelve (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the text of the Acts of Peter and the Twelve was completely unknown until its discovery at Nag Hammadi in 1945?

entry.title: Doug McKechnie (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that when Doug McKechnie played the "Big Moog", he was sometimes fueled by psychoactive drugs?

entry.title: If Books Could Kill (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that If Books Could Kill, there would be a podcast about it?
